intro: Quercus interruptella, commonly known as the Mexican white oak, is a deciduous tree native to central Mexico. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its white to pale gray bark and alternate, simple leaves. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Quercus interruptella typically grows in dry to moist forests and is adapted to a range of soil types. Its ecological role includes providing habitat and contributing to forest biodiversity.
